Fields.DialogueText: Does it start on the left foot? Or right foot? I can't remember how this cheer went... No. I'm sure it was right foot first and then spin...
OW!
Huh? Stewart! Are you all right?
Ouch! Hi, Captain. What brings you here today?
Uh... Stewart, your head is bleeding.
Is it? Hm... oh, that does feel... wet? Oh, dear. Oh, dear! Ha! I suppose it is, a little bit.
What were you doing, walking into a random corner down here, anyway?
Just got a bit careless. I'll be fine, sir. It takes more than a bump to slow me down!
What can I do for you?

Fields.MenuText: ... Your head is still bleeding.
What was that about?
You were muttering something about feet.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, don't you worry about that. I've heard Chinese locals say that a little mugwort stops the bleeding.
What was what about, sir? Just having a grand old time down on my ship.
Oh, the cheer. I saw a group of sailors doing a cheer when they thought no one was looking. I want to know their moves exactly, but I'd rather not ask them...
*ALARM*
Looks like we have company. Are you ready to fight?
Ah. Oof... I might be a little dizzy, but no matter. Let's drive those Morganas from these waters! We can DO IT!
@BATTLE
"That our flag was still therrrrrrrrrrre! Oh, say does that star spangled..."
Ooof.
Hello, Captain! Rough day?
Tell me about it...
Hey, why are you in my quarters?!
I thought a surprise would cheer you up...
Really? Quite thoughtful of you!
... and also because I left my scrapbook here.
I didn't know you made scrapbooks. What's in there?
All kinds of memories! I haven't been back to the States since I reported to the Asiatic Fleet around... hm... 1922?
For someone so patriotic, I can't imagine it's been easy being away from your homeland for so long.
I've been all around the Pacific - to the Philippines, Japan, and just all over the Chinese coast. And more!
And every place I visited is represented in this scrapbook, here.
See this? A letter from a marine from Shanghai. Heh, the look on his face when he tried Peking duck for the first time... oh, it was pure joy.
And what about this page here? It has some kind of strange mark...
Ha... you don't have to look at that one! Just... just some grubby old page... heh...

Fields.MenuText: You sure that's all it was?
You're acting like there's a dead body in that book.
Why would you keep an old page like that?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, sir! You know, I could go for a bite of some good buttered toast. How about you?
Dead... body? No. Why would there be a dead body in a book?
Why wouldn't I? There are no guidelines to say what I can and can't have in my scrapbook.
Uh...
Anyway, time to prep the crew... for the next wave of BFs headed straight toward us!
You couldn't have warned me sooner?
And we've got just enough time for a quick cheer before they get here! Gimme a "U"! Gimme an "S"! Gimme an "A"!
@BATTLE
Well... no. Not easy. But there've been some good times along the way!
Well, well, well - look who we have here! Enemy contacts coming over the horizon, Captain!
I see them. Good eye, Stewart!
Ahem... "O beautiful for spacious skies, for amber waves of grain!"
Stewart?
"A-MER-ica! A-MER-ica! God shed His grace on THEEEEEE!"
Let's... just get started... with the battle...
@BATTLE
"From sea to shining SEAAAAAAAAA!"
You really extended the song, Stewart...
A war cry keeps the crew in high spirits throughout the battle, Captain! I wanted to stir their hearts!
War cry? "America the Beautiful" isn't a war cry.
Huh? Who's to say it isn't, now? If it invigorates the crew and prepares us for battle, then it most certainly is a war cry, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: You're not wrong.
I'm sure our non-American crew members just love the anthem.
I can't argue, can I?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not. We must do all we can to ready ourselves for the coming fights.
... Maybe they appreciate the melody?
Nope, not at all. Hee.
Consider singing along with me next time, Captain?
Attention, all hands! We've got enemy contact!
@BATTLE
Ow! What are those things, Stewart?
Huh? What ever could you mean, Captain?
During the battle, something was shining in the sunlight. It blinded me for a bit. The light was horizontal and there were two of them... it was coming from you.
Huh... horizontal lights and they were... two of them... Oh! You must mean my ivory chopsticks. I always keep them around as a good luck charm.
Why's that?
In a war, we never know what tomorrow will bring. I always figure a bit of superstition or maybe even a lucky charm can't hurt!
I understand that, but why ivory chopsticks?
Oh! Do you know what drinking games are, sir?

Fields.MenuText: Do I want to know how this story ends?
Yes?
No... at least, I don't know what a Belle's definition of them are.

Fields.DialogueText: The story is not that bad, sir.
You sound a little uncertain, Captain.
Drinking games are the same for Belles as they are for humans, sir.
Anyway, one of the sailors bet his prized ivory chopsticks that he could outdrink me.
After I finished my twentieth beer, the poor guy was passed out cold, but his friend told me I won and gave me his chopsticks.
I can't tell if it was just by luck that I won, but it's nice that I won something so valuable just from drinking.
You still haven't answered why you think the chopsticks are lucky...
Hah. Watch, when I put these in my hair...
Should you really put something that valuable in your hair? What if they...
*CRACK*
... break?
Waaaaah! Noooooo...
Maybe they weren't so lucky...
Morgana contacts inbound! All hands, report to battlestations!
@BATTLE
Oh, memories. How painful they can be...
Stewart?
Oh, hello there, sir. How may I be of assistance?
I was wondering about something. You've spent a lot of time in the Pacific Ocean, before the war. And I know you helped out with the relief effort in Japan after the earthquake.
Earthquake?
I overheard one of the old salts in the crew talking about the destruction of the Great Kanto earthquake firsthand.
I asked him about it. I thought it might have something to do with that scrapbook page you didn't want me to see.
Well well well... don't you just belong in your own detective novel?
Heh.
Yes, our ship was sent to assist the victims of that horrible earthquake. We received many honors, but it paled in comparison to...

Fields.MenuText: To what?
What was on the page in the scrapbook, then?
How bad was it?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't really want to discuss it now, sir.
The devastation was indescribable.
Sorry, but can we change the subject, Captain?
If this is something that you-
I think maybe I've got something in my eye. Just going to find a sink and try to flush it out. By your leave, sir!
Okay. "Don't search for clues about your own Belle." Note taken.
Huff. Just a few more crates. Hrnngghhhh... "We can LIFT them, yes we CAN..." Oof...
Whoa! How many crates do you have stacked there? Are you moving all of these yourself?
Hello, Captain! Just moving the last of these provisions to the galley.
Mind if I help?
Not at all! Would it help if I did a cheer?
Um... I had a question, first.
How did you end up responsible for moving these crates around? On your own, I mean.
I have strong shoulders! Never underestimate my brawn, Captain! Despite my appearance, I can lift far more than anybody on the crew.

Fields.MenuText: I don't typically think of you as being stronger than me... but, now that you mention it, you probably are.
Belles are sure full of surprises, huh?
You know, for being as strong as you are, you don't seem to have much in the way of muscle definition.

Fields.DialogueText: Not probably. It is a certainty!
Heh. We always are, Captain!
I guess a Belle's biology just works differently than a human's.
*ALARM*
Ugh, more Morganas. These crates will have to wait. Ready, Stewart?
Hee hee. MORE-ganas. Guess we never have to worry about running out of them, do we?
Hmph.
Always ready, sir!
@BATTLE
Hm... maybe we shouldn't call them the "BF"...
Huh? What are you talking about, Stewart?
The BF? That's what we American Belles call the Morganas. The Bitch Fleet! Ha! But maybe that's a bit harsh, don't you think?
Stewart, they're endangering humanity for no apparent reason. Don't you think they deserve harsh?
I-I know, sir. But... what if we're misunderstanding them? What if they have their reasons, and we're just making the situation worse by antagonizing them?
If they have legitimate reasons for their actions, then they should have sought a peaceful solution. That's all there is to it.
Oh, Mary...
Huh?
Oh, nothing, sir. Now, help me pass out this cha shao bao to the crew while they're hot.
Wait...
Oh, don't worry, sir, I used my own allowance to make this from scratch.

Fields.MenuText: Who's Mary?
What are you trying to hide, Stewart?
As long as you didn't go over budget.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no one, sir. Don't worry about it. Oooh, this is a big bao. Here you go, sir!
Hide? Maybe I'm hiding this bao away. Hee, kidding. Here, sir.
Of course not. The wellbeing of the crew comes first. Here's a good sized bao, sir.
Ah, thanks. This is... delicious!
*ALARM*
Oh, no! The BF... oh, I mean...  how about...  Best Friends?
.... Really?
It's the best I could come up with, all right?
@BATTLE
Damn! The Morganas are changing course. Did they just acquire a new target?
They're headed toward civilian ships!
Get your guns ready, Stewart. We've got to find a way to intercept them.
Stewart?
You know, I've tried my best to sympathize with them, but then... they do something like this. I will NOT allow them to hurt the innocent!
I don't think they care about our sympathy.
Their actions really are unforgivable. Let's go after them! Now! FLANK SPEED!
RAH, RAH, RAH! They're full of RUST! Beat the Morganas down to the DUST! Gooooo, Team STEWART!
Don't get reckless, Stewart! We still need to use some caution. That's a sizeable Morgana fleet.
The lives of many are at risk, sir. Are you saying we should let them be slaughtered?

Fields.MenuText: No, but...
Let's plan this out before we go in...
You're right, Stewart. Our priorities are crystal clear!

Fields.DialogueText: But, what? Hesitation only wastes time that can be spent saving others.
What planning do we need? People who need to be saved, so we go in and save them! That's all there is to it. Nothing more, nothing less, Captain!
Then what are you saying? Think a little more before speaking, Captain!
Uh... I meant to say "with all due respect" first.
Quite all right, Stewart.
We're going in FAST, and that is THAT! Pound the Morganas - beat 'em down FLAT!
@BATTLE
Hey, Captain, ready for a fight? Morganas on the horizon!
@BATTLE
Ah, there you are. Listen, we've got a minor problem in the engine room with the-
"... leads me beside quiet waters..." Ah, I could really use something like that!
Ahem.
Oh! Sorry, had my nose in a book. Was that bad? Did I miss something important?
I don't mind you reading, Stewart. It's as good a pastime as any.
It does help me a lot. After all, it can be hours or days or weeks between battles!
Just promise me you won't smack your face into a bulkhead while you're walking around reading.
I promise!
What's the book?
Ah, it's nothing. What do you need? You said something about the engine room?
Yeah - but I just remembered something else. Did you move those documents that were on my desk somewhere?
Mmm... I imagine you might find them near the galley.
What? Why would you put them there?
Hm, good question! I don't remember myself...

Fields.MenuText: Did you sleepwalk?
How can you not remember picking up pieces of paper from your captain's desk?
You realize that's strange behavior, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be silly, Captain, I've never done such a thing in my life.
I can remember picking them up and putting them in the galley... I just don't remember why I put them there.
Well, I've certainly heard of stranger.
Well, at least you remember where you put them. Sorry to disturb your reading, Stewart.
Oh, no trouble at all. Please stop by again if you need me, Captain.
That was close...
What?
Nothing!
Stewart? Stewart, are you-
Just report to engineering when you get a chance, okay?
*nods sweetly*
Five, six, seven, eight! Show them that our fleet is great! Every woman, every man! BF won't gain the upper hand!
That's the spirit, Stewart!
You got it, Captain! We-
Aaaaaaah...! Get it off of me! Get it off!
Stewart? What's wrong? Calm down.
It's on my face! Cold! Stinging! Gritty! Get it off of me, please, sir!
Okay, Okay, take it easy. Let me take a look, all right? Hm?
Did you rub it away? The seawater. It's all over my face...
Wait, you were startled by... water?
Ah... y-yes...
You know you... live on the water, right?

Fields.MenuText: Did I say something wrong?
Huh?
I was trying to be funny, Stewart.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, no sir, it's fine.
Nothing, sir. Don't pay me any attention!
I apologize, sir. I didn't understand.
Anyway... hah, that's better. Back to my cheer! Fight, fight, fight! Go... Team Stewart!
That was a fast rebound.
We've got a fight to win, Captain!
@BATTLE
ONE... and... TWO. Great! THREE and FOUR! Yay! Aaaand... FIVE and- Sir, look out!
Whoa! Careful now, Stewart. You almost hit me.
Daijoubu? Are you all right?
Yeah, I think I'm fine. Were you practicing martial arts or something? That kick looked like it could have knocked a person's skull off their shoulders.
Oh, that kick? That was a high kick. I learned that from a marine in Shanghai. I decided, "Why not combine this into a cheer?"
I call it...  The Sparkly Kick.
I'm sure your opponents would see some sparks if you connect that kick with their head.
Ha, you're right, sir! Points for you.

Fields.MenuText: Was that marine also a cheerleader instructor?
Why would he teach you something like that?
Was he a martial artist?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no, sir. I just decided to combine martial arts and cheerleading together. Personally, I think it quite the ingenious combination.
He didn't exactly teach me. I just picked it up from observing him.
No, just a marine, Captain... but one who knew it wouldn't hurt for him to learn some foreign fighting techniques.
Why don't you try this with me? Maybe you can show all the men and women back home what moves you learned during this war.
Ah, no, I'll pass. Thanks, Stewart. We actually have...
Darn! I sense it now. The BFs are here, aren't they?
@BATTLE
A little scrub and... there! All shiny and new again. The BF won't stand a chance.
And not a moment too soon! Enemies inbound!
@BATTLE
Hey, Stewart. I noticed before the Morganas approached that you were shining your boots.
Does it seem odd that I shine my boots before a battle? A frivolous luxury for high-class people, maybe?
That's not exactly what I was thinking.
No need to worry. Just taking good care of my galoshes! I learned the hard way that canvas shoes do little to shelter my poor feet....
But one day a kind, old woman approached me once on a pier. She said that if I took these galoshes off of her hands, she'd be thankful.
When I accepted her gift, a tired old smile creased her lips. She said, "I finally contributed to a good cause," and disappeared into the crowd.
Oh, I don't think I'll forget that experience any time soon. It made an impression on me.

Fields.MenuText: Hard to forget something like that, Stewart.
I wonder who that old woman was.
You really don't like getting wet, do you?

Fields.DialogueText: True, that kindness was... well, it meant much to me.
I wonder that as well, Captain.
In any case, you're a good person to take care of that for her, Stewart.
You think so? Thank you, sir. You make me blush.
Ah, it's nothing. I'm going to go check on the engine room. Do you want to come with me?
I'll join you in just a moment. I need to think about some things, if you don't mind.
Suit yourself, Stewart.
Hmm.
Captain! Morganas are bearing down on that civilian ship!
Make your best speed, Stewart. And get our guns firing to draw their attention.
Hey! Focus over here, BF! Leave those people alone and fight us!
@BATTLE
We were just trying to get away from the war zone. We never expected Morganas to attack us.
Are you sure that you are all right?
We are now. Thank you so much!
Oh... and this is my daughter, Lisa. Could you watch her for me for just a moment while I check on the other passengers? Thank you!
Wait, what?
Smile, sir! We should always glad to help.
Thank you for helping us, lady.
Call me Stewart! You can remember it like this... Gimme an "S!" Gimme a "T!" Now, gimme an "E!" Gimme a-
Um, excuse me, Stewart?
Yes?
You look so strong. Sometimes other kids pick on me, but I'm too small to fight back.
Do you know Saint Lawrence? He's a saint for cooks, comedians, and even firefighters! When things were bad, he laughed and never gave in.
He would... laugh? Why?
Even when you can't fight back, you can stay strong on the inside. Do you understand?
I think so. Oh! My father's waving to me that it's time to go. Bye!

Fields.MenuText: Hardly surprising, but you're great with kids, Stewart.
Interesting advice, Stewart.
Wasn't Saint Lawrence a martyr? A bit grim to tell a kid about him, don't you think?

Fields.DialogueText: You flatter me. I just wanted to help!
Just because she's a child doesn't mean she won't understand. Someday.
Life won't get better until the war is over, sir. She's got to learn how to survive and thrive.
Fair enough.
Aye aye, sir.
I'm heading to the bridge. Let me know when all the civilians have safely disembarked.
Hoo! I'm famished! I could go for a good, crispy, duck right about now.
Worry about that later, Stewart. Morganas are approaching.
But... I'm so hungry...
I'll get you some duck if we make it out of this alive.
Done deal! We'll do more than come out alive. We're going to triumph! Hoorah, men! ONE, TWO, and THREE cheers for US! Hoorah!
@BATTLE
Oh. This duck... It's just lovely. Taste that skin, Captain! Caramelized duck skin... So crisp and juicy! Oh... this is a fine Peking Duck! NOM!
Honestly, I'm surprised I was even able to find Peking Duck.
Surprised? Why's that?
I got lost in the city trying to find a place that served the dish. I finally stumbled across a restaurant that did, but then finding my way back to the ship was no easy task.
Lost or not, you did well rewarding me, sir. Here, have a bite of the duck as a job well done.

Fields.MenuText: Ah, no. You deserve it, Stewart. I can't.
But I don't really eat meat.
Sorry. Staying away from meat.

Fields.DialogueText: No, it's all right, sir. I insist! Really!
Not even one little bite? No one is looking but me, Captain.
Just a tiny bite doesn't count as meat! It's like air with a bit of flavoring!
Oh, fine. Here goes... It's... Oh, my. It's delicious.
Right? You should always try new things! It's not fun living life with so many reasons to say no!
That's okay. Eat yours for both of us.
Well, okay. But you'd better brace yourself for a lot of lip-smacking and satisfied sighing!
Duly noted.
Excellent work on our patrol so far, Stewart. We're steady on course and ready for anything.
Thanks, Captain! If you ask me, I'm ready for more of that Peking duck. Even the leftovers were incredible! BURP!
You and your appetites, Stewart. Honestly, I-
Sir! Look! New contacts! We have to turn immediately starboard before we drive into their formation!
Huh?
Hurry, there's not much time. Please!
All right. Crew, brace yourselves! We're making a hard turn to starboard. Hold on!
Eeeeeep!
Augh!
Whoa!
That was close! If we'd continued on our course a moment longer, we'd have been ambushed. The Morganas were setting a trap for us!

Fields.MenuText: What I wouldn't give for that sixth sense of yours.
How would we have fared if we had continued forward?
You did well, Stewart.

Fields.DialogueText: It does frequently come in handy.
Casualties would have been inevitable, I'm afraid.
Thank you, sir.
Morganas are shifting their formation. Looks like they realized we caught onto their plan.
Right! All hands, get to battle stations!
@BATTLE
Fight! Fight! FIGHT to the death! Yeah! Ho-hah!
@BATTLE
I'll never know why we can't have a little more rum on this ship. I keep telling the supply officer to requisition-
Stewart? Whoa, is that Johnny on the deck down there? Is he all right?!
Oh, he's fine. He had a little too much to drink, I suppose.
You... suppose? Are you sure he's even still breathing?!
We took the remaining rations on board and divided it amongst us two to see who could drink the most. Just to see what would happen.
My rum...
Anyway, he passed out after five. This is my, um, thirtieth, I believe.

Fields.MenuText: Thirty? How are you not dead?
Why did you two suddenly decide to have a drinking contest?
Five seems kind of low.

Fields.DialogueText: You forget that I am not exactly human, Captain.
Honestly? We just felt like it. I figured it might be fun for morale.
Oh, that's five bottles of rum, sir. He is by no means a lightweight!
Cheers! Umph. Oh, Mary...
Say what, now?
Don't worry, sir. I can hold my liquor. I was just about to work on a new cheer, actually!
Morganas detected! All hands, report to battlestations!
@BATTLE
... and hurry! We don't have much time, so tell the others to get back here as soon as you can, all right?
Yes, Miss Stewart!
Stewart, what are you up to?
Oh! Captain! Uhhhh... How wonderful to see you! Want to hear a new cheer?
Right. You're definitely hiding something. What's going on?
Golly! You sound awfully suspicious, sir. Why is that?
Because I see a crate moving... on its own power... across the brow and onto the pier. There wouldn't be a few sailors hiding under that crate, would there?
Run, men! RUN!
Stop! Hold it right there! What's the meaning of all this, Stewart?
I needed them to go ashore for a little while, sir.
So why not tell me, instead of forcing those sailors to look like they're in some silly cartoon?
Because they're not officially on shore leave. They're going to help some civilians in my place.
Why wouldn't I allow that?
Huh?
Some volunteer work? Seems like a noble thing. Why would I deny that?
I... don't know...

Fields.MenuText: Stewart, you don't have to be bashful. You can tell me what you want or what you're feeling.
I think you do know.
You don't have to be scared of me, Stewart. Not as long as we're doing our duty.

Fields.DialogueText: All right. Thank you, Captain.
I was just afraid you'd say no. I promise not to hide things like this from you, sir.
I know, Captain. It just takes me a while to trust new people.
Hey! You, down there!
Yes, Captain?
I'm granting you and the others shore leave for Stewart's job, but be back as soon as you're done. And leave the crate on the pier.
Aye aye, Captain!
Thank you, sir! I'll never forget this.
Stewart, I have a...
Oh, goodness... Goodness! Whoa... whoa... ahhhh! Almost got it... NO! Don't fall in the ocean, pretty please?
Careful, Stewart. You're leaning over that railing...
Hairpin-san, please, don't move another inch. There... it stopped. Phew!
What was that about?
Oh, hello there, Captain! I was going to clean my hairpin, when my fingers fumbled over it, like a football inches from the end zone.
Maybe you shouldn't play with that hairpin topside where there's a chance it could fall overboard.
But I heard you calling for me! I can't stay inside when you need me.
Eh, it wasn't so urgent, Stewart. Where did you get that hairpin, anyway?
One of the Japanese earthquake victims left it on the ship. A sailor tried to return it to her, but she left before he could.
I keep it with me at all times, in case I ever see her again.

Fields.MenuText: Quite a pretty pin.
A poetic story. The earthquake was years ago.
"Again?" You didn't actually see her, though. You weren't there as a Belle for the rescue.

Fields.DialogueText: Isn't it? I've grown so attached to it... Oh! But don't think I wouldn't give it back to the original owner if I saw her!
It makes me wonder what her life is like now.
Although it happened years before I awakened as a Belle, I have indirect memories of it because this ship was there. It's kinda tricky to explain...
Think she's living a good life, all this time later? I'd love to do a special cheer for her!
This ship's efforts made a difference back then. That survivor is better off, I'm sure.
Thanks, sir.
Ah, finally! I've got the pin safely in my hair. All better... and now we have the BF to attend to!
@BATTLE
No time to rest! All hands to battlestations!
@BATTLE
For the safety of everyone in the future... and for the peace of everyone already dead...
Stewart?
... now and at the hour of our death...
What are those beads you have in your hands?
Huh?! Nothing! Nothing at all. Have I shown you the latest cheer I've invented?
Your latest cheer? Stewart, you're changing the subject.
No, I'm not. I mean... maybe I am.

Fields.MenuText: Why do you act fishy around me?
What are the beads for? Are those-?
What were you saying earlier, before you noticed me? That was definitely NOT a cheer.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not acting fishy, Captain.
Nothing! Nothing at all.
What was I saying?
Every girl, even a cheerleader, needs some private time, sir. Can I be dismissed? Thanks! Bye, sir!
Stewart? Please wait a moment...
One, two, three, FOUR! On the "FOUR" is when we jump, like this! Come on, crew, do it with me! Aaaaand... JUMP!
When I enlisted, I never expected to have cheer practice on a warship... but this does get me a little more excited to fight the Morganas!
I'm glad you said so. I didn't want to be the only one to admit it!
Aaaand KICK! Good job, everyone! You've done so well today! Now we've got the right spirit to tackle the BF! Let's KICK their behinds!
Dismissed, crew. Get to your battle stations.
Aye aye, Captain!
@BATTLE
Sniffle... huff... huff... sniffle...
Stewart? What are you doing in my quarters again?
Oh...
Stewart? Are you crying?
Captain, I'm sorry, you shouldn't see me like this. Stewart, the cheer squad captain, shouldn't be crying, should she?!
Talk to me. What's going on?
I can't really talk about it right now.

Fields.MenuText: When can you talk about it? You're part of my crew, Stewart.
Is there someone that you're hiding from?
Can you give me a hint what it's about?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know, just not now. Some other time, I think.
You.
No.
I'm probably just tired from that battle. Sorry for hiding in your cabin, sir.
Great. How do you cheer up a cheerleader?
Hiding from me in my own quarters is a little bit strange, don't you think?
Uhhh....
Morgana forces spotted! All hands, report to battlestations!
@BATTLE
Captain, have a look at this page in my scrapbook. I think you'll like it.
Hm? What makes you say that?
Just look!
Malvern, Pennsylvania?
A small town, but lovely. Real Americana, you know? Railroads cross right through it, too.
Why is this town in your scrapbook?
There was a marine on board this ship, one whom I liked very much, and Malvern was his hometown.
You can see here in his letter, how he would hop trains as a boy to attend concerts in Philadelphia.
That's a bold thing to do. Hardly surprising for a marine!
Wandering was in his blood. During a port call in the Pacific, he decided he wanted to live in Japan and never returned back home.
A deserter, eh? That must have been difficult, especially considering you liked him as much as you did.

Fields.MenuText: I said something wrong again, didn't I?
Your face says it all, Stewart, I'm sorry.
Did I hurt you?

Fields.DialogueText: You're fine.
Nothing is wrong. Everything's fine, sir.
No, you did not. You have nothing to regret, Captain.
But-
Please, for the sake of me being able to heal, accept that you are not in the wrong, sir.
Understood. But talk to me sometime soon, all right?
Aye aye, sir.
Whew! Another great practice. That cheer will get the crew ready for a good fight! Time to-
Stewart? Are you cheering down here?
O-HO! NO, YOU DON'T!
Pardon me?! That's no way to greet your captain.
Oh! Hee hee... Sorry, Captain, but I wasn't talking to you.
I was talking to that steel pillar. I almost smacked my face into it when I whirled around.
Hm? Avoiding pillars and beams, now?
Oh, yes! Remember how I kept bumping into things and hurting myself?
Hard to forget, Stewart.
Well, not anymore! I'm staying aware of my surroundings! Whether I'm dancing or scrapbooking, I am determined to develop my pillar avoidance.

Fields.MenuText: Painful lessons can be the most effective ones.
I like that attitude. I'm proud of you!
Finally! I wondered how many blows to the head it would take before you figured it out.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I agree...
Thanks, sir.
Oh, my! I wasn't expecting you to say it like... that. Then again, I can't really disagree with you, sir.
If you can master this, you can conquer the world, Stewart!
Conquer? I don't know about that, but once I've mastered the skill, maybe I inspire more people who need to overcome their own problems!
@BATTLE
Captain! Captainnnnn!
Stewart, we're standing close enough that you can probably use my binoculars without taking them off my neck.
So you're saying...
I'm saying there's no need to shout.
Sometimes I forget that I'm not cheering... but I just thought of a question. Do you ever think so much that your head hurts?

Fields.MenuText: I get hangovers sometimes.
Not really, no.
Sometimes my head hurts when YOU think too much, Stewart.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! I said, "think too much," not "drink too much"!
Oh.
Ha! Maybe a really loud CHEER will help, then!
I've got some good news, sir. I know that sometimes I think about bad things, and I get a little bit... strange.
It happens to all of us.
But now I'm going to follow my own advice! I'm going to keep my spirits up, stay strong, and not let bad things paralyze me.
Glad to hear it, Stewart. We all have to pick ourselves back up when we get knocked down.
Exactly! If I take one hit from a Morgana, should I just... SINK? I don't THINK so!
Well...
Oh! That could make a superb cheer! I should start practicing that one!
Before you do that-
Why wait? I should get started right away!
Take a look off the starboard quarter and you might see why.
The BF!
Fine, but then after the fight I need to get to cheer practice right away!
@BATTLE
That's not exactly what I-
Just kidding!
Listen up, crew! We've got a big fight coming up, so we need to rally! Give me a "B!" Give me an "F!" What does that SPELL?
"Biff"?
Wait... I think maybe it's "Beff"!
Sigh... Just get to your battle stations! Go! Fight! WIN!
@BATTLE
Oh, dear, sir! You're hurt! I'll grab a first aid kit and get you cleaned up in no time at all!
I'll be fine, Stewart. If anybody else needs some medical attention, help them out first.
Hang on sir! Cling to life! I'll never leave a soldier behind! I'LL SAVE YOU!
That's not necessary, Stewart, but I appreciate the concern.
What's not necessary?
Just a little scratch, nothing serious. Look, the bleeding has already stopped.
Oh.
You can calm down, Stewart. I'm not going to die on you.
You're... you're going to be fine. Just fine...

Fields.MenuText: I'm more concerned about you right now, Stewart.
What did I do this time?
We're both going to be fine, Stewart.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm... I'm fine.
Nothing, sir. I'm... I'm fine.
You're... you're right. You're right!
I started to panic when I saw a little bit of blood, but you're right. You're fine, and so am I.
This is a nice change, Stewart.
Honestly, I'm a little embarrassed... but I'll get over that, too.
You've got this.
I do, sir!
Captain, can I have a word with you? I've decided it's time to explain some things.
Sure. Close the cabin door behind you, and we can have a talk.
Remember that scrapbook page I tried to hide from you? It was from the Great Kanto earthquake.
This ship helped with relief efforts. While I hadn't awakened as a Belle yet, I sense memories of the disaster because our ship was there.
So many thousands of people died. Including children. Even the survivors suffered so much... It still rattles me, now and then.

Fields.MenuText: So now you try to cheer people up, to compensate?
A tragic loss, Stewart.
Often we can't do much about a disaster except take care of survivors.

Fields.DialogueText: I do.
Indeed. It can really take the wind from your sails, sir.
But I'll always try!
That's what my cheerleading is all about! I don't want our crew or anybody else to despair.
And when I catch you talking to yourself? It's not just talking, is it?
A Catholic chaplain visited the ship, once. He gave me a rosary and a Bible, and it... it just felt right. Now my faith helps me face the day.
But why hide being religious, Stewart?
I'm the Belle. Our cheerleader, Captain! If they ever saw me feeling down or asking for strength, would that make me a phoney?
I'm not sure the crew would see it that way... but it's your decision. Just don't bother hiding it from your captain.
Agreed.
I'm not going to forget the bad things or stop missing those who are gone, but I won't let it stop me from always doing my best!

Fields.MenuText: Thank you for trusting me, Stewart.
I'll always be here for you, Stewart.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for listening, Captain.
That means a lot to me, Captain.
